definitions.definition: an attractive quality of movement that is smooth and done with control; a simple and beautiful quality

examples.text: She moves with the natural grace of a ballerina.
a debut album of uncommon grace and beauty

definitions.definition: a quality of behaviour that is polite and pleasant and deserves respect

examples.text: He conducted himself with grace and dignity throughout the trial.

definitions.definition: ways of behaving that people think are polite and acceptable

examples.text: He was not particularly well versed in the **social graces**.

definitions.definition: extra time that is given to somebody to enable them to pay a bill, finish a piece of work, etc.

examples.text: They've given me a month's grace to get the money.

definitions.definition: the love that God shows towards the human race

examples.text: It was only by the grace of God that they survived.
The mantra bestows Siva's grace upon the devotee.

definitions.definition: a short prayer that is usually said before a meal to thank God for the food
used as a title of respect when talking to or about an archbishop, a duke or a duchess

examples.text: Their Graces the Duke and Duchess of Kent.

definitions.definition: a way of behaving that shows that somebody thinks that they are more important, etc. than they really are

examples.text: Even when he became a star he didn’t have any airs and graces.

definitions.definition: to have somebody’s approval and be liked by them
to lose the trust or respect that people have for you, especially by doing something bad or morally wrong
a situation in which somebody loses the trust or respect that people have for them, especially because they have done something that is bad or morally wrong

examples.text: The biography explains the circumstances surrounding her fall from grace.

definitions.definition: to be polite enough to do something, especially when you have done something wrong

examples.text: He didn't even have the grace to look embarrassed.

definitions.definition: (in the Roman Catholic Church) having been forgiven by God for the wrong or evil things you have done

examples.text: He died in a state of grace.

definitions.definition: used to say that you could easily have been in the same difficult or unpleasant situation that somebody else is in
in an unwilling and/or rude way

examples.text: He handed over the money with typical bad grace.

definitions.definition: in a willing and pleasant way

examples.text: You must learn to accept defeat with good grace.
We will simply have to accept the situation with a good grace.

definitions.definition: any particular year after the birth of Christ

wordOrigin: Middle English: via Old French from Latin gratia, from gratus ‘pleasing, thankful’; related to grateful.
